repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - First, Second, and Third Natural
            Resources and Environmental Governance Development Policy
            Operations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Natural Resources and Environmental Governance Development
            Policy Operations (DPO) Project for Ghana were as follows:
            outcome was moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: earmarking
            funds from a DPO to specific agencies can partly undermine
            the choice of instrument. There is a risk that in sectoral
            DPOs with one-year operational cycles, technical and policy
            advice to the client can be crowded out by processing
            requirements. Program documents should clearly distinguish
            between the description of policy areas and the program
            being implemented, the specific prior actions and triggers,
            and the indicators needed to assess performance. Sectoral
            development policy operations may need complementary
            technical assistance and support. Sectoral development
            policy operation programs should include a long-term plan
            for addressing what will happen at the end of the program.
            Introducing parallel financing into a sector with harmonized
            budget support can fracture harmonization. It can encourage
            government agencies to focus on bilateral relationships with
            individual development partners rather than engagement
            through the harmonized mechanisms. Civil society can play a
            useful role in natural resource management if government and
            civil society groups are able to collaborate productively.
            Creating and publishing environmental ratings of large
            companies can help to provide public pressure on the private
            sector to improve environmental performance.

19801742.trustfund:
TF090632-GHANA: NATURAL RESOURCES AND
            ENVIRONMENTAL GOVERNANCE PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - First, Second, and Third
            Development Policy Operations for the Natural Resources and
            Environmental Governance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Development Policy Operations for the Natural Resources and
            Environmental Governance Project for Ghana were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            transition from financing individual projects to sector
            budget support (SBS) rejuvenated ownership, and
            revolutionized multi-agency dialogue. Although difficult to
            quantify, the adoption of an SBS program based around a
            government-led target-setting process resulted in a much
            greater sense of ownership, empowerment and enthusiasm
            amongst the implementing Ministries, Departments and
            Agencies (MDA) than previous, discrete project investments.
            It also engendered a far more active dialogue between the
            sector MDAs, and more substantive engagement with both
            Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (MoFEP) and
            National Development Planning Commission (NDPC).
            Particularly in the case of the environment, this engagement
            was considered crucial to improving the understanding of
            environmental and climate change issues, and to
            mainstreaming environment through e.g. development of
            Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA) tools for
            government planning. It has also allowed effective
            collaboration on financial performance, particularly in
            regard to the work of the Revenue Management Task Force in
            the mineral sector. NREG was worked in two parallel arenas,
            policy reform (the primary focus of Development Policy
            Operation, or DPOs) and strengthening sector management
            systems (the primary focus of SBS). These should be
            complementary, but delivery through a single instrument may
            have complicated both. The SBS modality emphasized broad
            engagement in sector activities rather than focusing on
            select policy issues, whereas use of a World Bank DPO
            template as the key program document encouraged the use of
            the PAF as a primary planning tool and de-emphasized
            specific investments in sector systems, such as monitoring
            and evaluation (M&E) and technical assistance (TA). A
            broad sector program, addressing challenges in institutional
            capacity as well as policy reform, may be better supported
            by a DPO in conjunction with other types of instruments. In
            practice, sector DPOs, such as the forestry and environment
            DPO in Cameroon, are often supported by an additional TA
            facility. Structured TA support will have been especially
            important in NREG as the initial analytical work established
            a policy agenda, but not the detailed reforms needed to
            pursue it.

15625883.trustfund:
TF090632-GHANA: NATURAL RESOURCES AND
            ENVIRONMENTAL GOVERNANCE PROJECT

repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Natural resources and environmental governance

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about Natural
            Resources and Environmental Governance (NREG) Program in
            Ghana. The challenges of the program were to improve
            transparency in systems and procedures for natural resource
            management, and improve surveillance of timber trade.
            Government developed a five-year program of policy and
            institutional reforms and capacity building to improve
            natural resource and environmental governance. International
            Development Association (IDA) and other development partners
            were supporting government to implement this program through
            sector budget support, and technical assistance. The
            government had addressed important institutional reforms
            that were enhancing its ability to address priority natural
            resource management and environmental challenges. With NREG,
            a one-stop shop for assistance to Ghana on natural resources
            governance was a very significant achievement in itself. IDA
            support has assisted the country to prepare to manage the
            environmental implications of developing oil and gas
            reserves, and put in place a process to manage and mitigate
            the impacts of climate change.

12972791.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Third Natural Resources and
            Environmental Governance Development Policy Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Natural Resources
            and Environmental Governance Third Development Policy
            Operation (DPO) Program for Ghana are to: (a) ensure
            predictable and sustainable financing for the forest and
            wildlife sectors and effective forest law enforcement; (b)
            improve mining sector revenue collection, management, and
            transparency; (c) address social issues in forest and mining
            communities; and (d) mainstream environment into economic
            growth through Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA),
            Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), and development of a
            climate change strategy. The DPO focuses on supporting the
            Government's plans to invest in demand and supply-side
            approaches in order to improve governance in the natural
            resources sector and specifically target improved revenue
            management, financial flows and livelihoods in the forestry,
            wildlife and mining sub-sectors. The DPO will support
            Government of Ghana (GoG) actions that enable dialogue with
            complementary funding facilities for expanded civil society
            engagement in natural resources governance. The expected
            outcomes at the end of the DPO series include: (i) improved
            management of government revenues and finances in the
            forestry and mining sectors; (ii) reduced illegal logging;
            (iii) reduced social conflict in forestry and mining
            communities; and (iv) integration of environmental
            considerations into policy formulation and implementation
            across government, including risks associated with climate change.
